Chaoyue R. Wang

Twitter GitHub CV Email

Hi there! Welcome to my personal website!

I grew up in an industrial town in Chongqing, China, and went to Beijing for my undergraduate education. Currently I am a senior student of Philosophy, Politics and Economics1 at Peking University. I also go by Raphael, my Catholic name.

Broadly interested in race and ethnic politics and political behavior in the realm of American politics, I study the dynamics between racial identities and political polarization. My research examines how racial imageries—people’s racialized imagination of politically relevant categories—shape people’s perception of politics, and drive a diversifying America toward affective as well as ideological extremes. To accurately capture the content of racial imageries and their political implications, I draw upon an extensive range of data sources including public opinion surveys, census data, and administrative records.

A passionate user2, I enjoy applying powerful packages provided by the R community to visualize cross-sectional and time-series patterns of American political behavior in both static and interactive forms. I do this mostly for fun but also to help myself uncover interesting modes in American politics that otherwise might be elusive to spot. Check some of the graphs I proudly made with the help of {tidyverse} in the Gaphics page.

Education

  • BA in Philosophy, Politics and Economics (PPE) | July 2023 | Peking University
  • Exchange Student, ASAP Parterships | December 2021 | University of Notre Dame

Research Interests

  • American Politics
  • Race and Ethnic Politics (REP)
  • Political Behavior
  • Public Opinion
  • Politics of Identity
  • Racial Imagery
  • Social Cleavage
  • Partisanship
  • Affective Polarization

Footnotes

  1. Rather than three individual majors as it may confusingly sound like, Philosophy, Politics and Economics (PPE) is actually one combined, interdisciplinary major that originates from the University of Oxford in the 1920s.↩︎

  2. is actually such a powerhouse that I can almost conduct finish every stage of a research project entirely within the environment of RStudio , from data cleaning to in-depth analyses to writing the final manuscript! And despite my unapologetic love for R, I did set out my journey of quantitative social science in the arms of Stata, which I still use once in while for its stability and clarity in inspecting and labeling data.↩︎
